DISEASE: Encephalopathy, Progressive, Early-onset, With Episodic Rhabdomyolysis
RECORD:
Rare disease patients have complex clinical representations. Patients with Encephalopathy, Progressive, Early-onset, With Episodic Rhabdomyolysis present clinical features that include: early-onset progressive encephalopathy, episodic rhabdomyolysis, and recurrent infections. The most common underlying cause is a mutation in the gene encoding the lysosomal enzyme tripeptidyl peptidase I (TPP1). The clinical phenotype is variable, and can include epilepsy. Some special cases also present with cerebral calcifications.

This is a rare disease, with an estimated incidence of 1:1,000,000. The disease is more common in males than in females.

The disease is caused by mutations in the TPP1 gene. This gene is located on the long arm of chromosome 1 (1q21.1). The gene encodes the enzyme tripeptidyl peptidase I, which is involved in the degradation of neuropeptides.
